Emotional reactions to the 3D virtual body and future willingness: the effects of self-esteem and social physique anxiety

Emotional reactions to the 3D virtual body and future willingness: the effects of self-esteem and social physique anxiety

  • Juyeon Park  ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0001-8948-23811 

Virtual Reality volume 22, pages1–11(2018)Cite this article

  • 791 Accesses

  • 4 Citations

  • Metrics details

Abstract

This study examined how the participant’s self-esteem and social physique anxiety affected the emotional reactions to viewing their own virtual body and willingness to participate in the virtual experience in the future. Three-dimensional body scanning technology was used as a virtual reality tool. Ninety-three (51 males and 42 females) subjects participated in the experiment, who were 18+ years old, both genders, and had no history of musculoskeletal or mental problems. The experiment consisted of the three phases, including the pre-scanning survey, 3D body scanning, and post-scanning evaluation. The results verified causal relationships that led to certain types of emotions after viewing the 3D virtual body and the willingness to participate in a future session, within the domains of self-esteem and social physique anxiety. Specifically, self-confidence (positive dimension of self-esteem) was strongly associated with positive emotions. The “other-oriented” perspective of social physique anxiety exhibited positive correlations with negative emotions. The participants who showed positive emotions indicated a strong willingness to participate in another session of 3D body scanning in the future, but those with negative emotions also showed their positive willingness to participate in the future session. It signified that regardless of their emotional responses (positive or negative) to viewing their 3D virtual body, the participants were willing to experience their 3D virtual body in the future. The findings suggested that this virtual reality approach could be used as a potentially effective, clinical tool for patients with body image-related disorders. Study limitations and future research were also discussed.

Introduction

Body image encompasses the inside view of one’s body, often reflected in one’s thoughts, beliefs, feelings, and behaviors (Cash 2004). Furthermore, body image is a multidimensional psychological construct that changes over time based on a person’s daily experiences and the sociocultural context in which he or she belongs (Bruchon-Schweitzer 1992). Attitudes toward body image are related to self-esteem (Cash and Pruzinsky 1990), and body dissatisfaction is often expressed through psychological distress and body image disturbance (Gardner 2002). Fox (1998) argued that one’s perception of his or her physical self is related to global self-concept. That is, individuals with high self-esteem tend to have high self-concept, whereas individuals with low self-esteem tend to have inconsistent or unsteady self-concept (Von Bergen and Soper 1996). Furthermore, one’s body is on constant display in any sociocultural milieu that evokes an array of emotions in the individual, and such emotions often lead to anxiety or feelings of inferiority associated with his or her physical self (Schlenker and Leary 1982). Especially in the contemporary normative cultural aesthetics, self-perception of actual vs. ideal body adversely influences people’s psychological and physical well-being, causing devalued and deviant self-identities (Dovidio et al. 2000), deteriorated mental health (Friedman et al. 2005), and overall negative quality of life (Fontaine et al. 2004; Link and Phelan 2006).

Studies have asserted that virtual reality technology is a clinically important emerging tool not only for the assessment of body image disturbance, but also for its treatment (Ferrer-García and Gutiérrez-Maldonado 2012; Riva et al. 2012). Riva and his colleagues (Riva 2011; Riva et al. 2012) elucidated the scientific benefits of virtual reality technology from the allocentric lock theory perspective. That is, individuals with body image disturbance tend to have a locked allocentric (third-person view) negative memory of the body and difficulty in transforming to the egocentric (first-person) view (De Vignemont and Frith 2005). As Riva et al. (2012) affirmed, virtual reality technology offers an effective means to facilitate the shift from one’s locked third-person view to the first-person view of the body by inducing a controlled sensory rearrangement in the virtual environment.

Three-dimensional (3D) body scanning technology is an innovative anthropometric solution that creates a 3D body surface model based on highly accurate body dimensional data using noninvasive depth sensors (Loker et al. 2004). The recent add-on of virtual reality (i.e., 3D avatar created based on one’s own body data) offers new possibilities for the technology in fields where a realistic visual representation of the body is necessary. While the practical advantages of the 3D body scanning technology have been recognized in many other fields, including apparel manufacturing, e-commerce (i.e., virtual try-on), video gaming, and animation, this study aimed to explore the potential of 3D body scanning technology as a virtual reality tool in the field of body image.

Given the sensitivity of the potential outcomes on one’s psychological well-being, user acceptance and emotional reactions must be evaluated prior to the actual implementation of the technology in any clinical setting. A handful of studies in literature, especially in the practice of garment fit analyses, have discussed user responses to 3D body scanning technology. For example, based on their observation, McKinnon and Istook (1999) illustrated that while being scanned, the participants experienced self-consciousness or embarrassment. On other hand, in a study of 3D body scanning with 203 female participants, Loker et al. (2004) found that after 3D scanning, nearly all participants (98%) said they would be willing to be scanned again, but only a little over half the participants (55%) reported they felt comfortable or very comfortable seeing their own scanned body on the computer screen. Furthermore, only 38% said they would be comfortable showing their scan to family and friends. Additionally, the researchers in the same study conducted an observational analysis of 22 selected participants (out of 203) on the participants’ verbal and nonverbal responses, facial expressions, and body language descriptions during the experiment process. The results of the observational analysis indicated overall positive responses, while some uneasiness was noted in the participants’ nonverbal and facial expressions. However, the observations and seven-point ratings were performed by the research assistants who operated the 3D body scanner (i.e., secondary evaluation), not by the participants, which rendered a serious flaw in data collection. Even though the results of the previous work may still need to be further validated, they suggest that while 3D body scanning experience was associated with some uneasy and unsettled feelings with seeing their scan image in the virtual form, people overall indicated their future willingness to participate in another session of 3D body scanning. Despite the existence of previous work on this topic, no research to date has illustrated user reactions to the 3D body scanning experience in clinical applications.

Given the dearth of the particular focus in current literature, the purpose of this study was to examine the effect of one’s self-concept (self-esteem) and anxiety associated with the physical self (social physique anxiety) on the emotional reactions to viewing his or her 3D virtual body (emotional responses) and willingness to participate in future 3D body scanning (future willingness), in the context of body image. Based on the understanding from the literature, this study formulated the following hypotheses to investigate the relationships among the participant’s self-esteem, social physique anxiety, emotions responses, and future willingness:

H 1

Higher self-esteem and lower social physique anxiety are associated with positive emotions aroused from the experience of viewing the 3D virtual body.

  • H1a Participants with higher self-esteem will show positive emotions after viewing their own 3D virtual body than those with lower self-esteem.

  • H1b Participants with lower social physique anxiety will show positive emotions after viewing their own 3D virtual body than those with higher social physique anxiety.

H 2

Lower self-esteem and higher social physique anxiety are associated with negative emotions aroused from the experience of viewing the 3D virtual body.

  • H2a: Participants with lower self-esteem will show negative emotions after viewing their own 3D virtual body than those with higher self-esteem.

  • H2b: Participants with higher social physique anxiety will show negative emotions after viewing their own 3D virtual body than those with lower social physique anxiety.

H 3

Emotions aroused from the experience of viewing the 3D virtual body are associated with the willingness to participate in a future session of 3D body scanning.

  • H3a: Positive emotions are positively associated with the willingness to participate in a future session of 3D body scanning.

  • H3b: Negative emotions are negatively associated with the willingness to participate in a future session of 3D body scanning.

Additionally, this study explored the potential effects of participants’ demographics (i.e., age, gender, BMI, and ethnicity) in the relationships among the psychological constructs, described above.

Methods

Participant recruitment

Study participants were recruited with the following inclusion criteria: those who were 18 years and older; both genders; and had no history of musculoskeletal or mental problems. The participants were recruited through flyers and e-blasts to local communities in the Western region of the USA. Recruitment flyers were posted on the bulletin boards at local churches, restaurants, libraries, and event centers. E-blasts were sent out to students and staff at the researcher’s university through the campus-wide e-mailing system. The recruitment materials guided interested people to contact the researcher to ask any questions about the research procedures and schedule for their participation. During the initial contact with the researcher, a potential participant’s demographics were pre-screened and those who did not meet the inclusion criteria were not scheduled to participate in the study. Prior to participation, each participant was asked to review and sign an informed consent form, approved by the institutional review board (IRB) of the researcher’s university, and scheduled to visit the laboratory where a 3D full-body scanner was located.

Experimental design and procedure

Each experiment consisted of three phases: the pre-scanning survey, 3D body scanning, and the post-scanning evaluation.

Pre-scanning

The pre-scanning survey asked for the participant’s demographic information (e.g., age, gender, ethnicity) and a battery of two standard scales of psychological constructs: Rosenberg’s self-esteem (SE) scale and the social physique anxiety (SPA) scale. The Rosenberg SE scale (Rosenberg 1965) contained 10 items that assessed global self-worth by measuring both positive and negative feelings about the self, using a five-point Likert scale format ranging from strongly disagree (1) to strongly agree (5). The SPA scale (Hart, Leary, and Rejeski 1989) was used to measure the participant’s feelings of anxiety associated with displaying his or her physique in social settings. The SPA scale featured a 12-item self-report scale developed to assess concerns regarding others’ evaluations of and one’s own feelings about one’s body on a five-point Likert scale ranging from not at all (1) to extremely (5).

Three-dimensional body scanning

The 3D body scanner ([TC]2, KX-16®) adopted for this study used depth sensors to capture a surface representation of approximately 300,000 spatial data points per scan. Prior to the 3D body scanning, the researcher walked through the procedure with the participants, who were given an opportunity to ask any questions they had about the data collection method. The participants were then asked to stand inside the full-body scanner and follow the audio prompt that directed them on how to pose within the scanner. They were scanned wearing their own undergarments, in which the scanner was covered by a black curtain, so that no one else but the participant had access to. Thus, the participant’s privacy was kept. For more accurate data, the body scanner was set to scan the body three times, automatically average the three sets of data, and produce a 3D surface model. The 3D scanning took 15–20 s on average.

Post-scanning

Upon completion of the 3D scanning, a virtual avatar (Fig. 1) was created based on the averaged body scan data, and the participants were allowed to view their virtual body on the computer screen, located in the same room as the 3D body scanner. The participants were instructed how to use software functions to navigate the 3D virtual body. When the participants indicated confidence in using the navigation functions, the researcher exited the scanning room to allow the participants to freely examine their virtual body model for as long as they desired. Post-viewing, the participants were guided to a conference room and asked to evaluate their emotions evoked from the 3D scanning experiment on the 15 scale items (for detailed items, please refer to Table 3). The pre-selected emotion types, included in the post-scanning evaluation survey, were adopted and modified from Higgins’ study of self-discrepancy (1987). Each emotion item was asked as such: After viewing the 3D image of my body, I felt “dissatisfied”, “frustrated”, “shameful”, and so on, using a five-point Likert scale. Additionally, at the end of the survey, the participants were asked to rate their willingness to participate in another session of 3D body scanning in the future, on a five-point Likert scale.

Data analysis

Descriptive and inferential data gathered from this study were analyzed using IBM SPSS 24.0. The data set consisted of pre- and post-scanning survey responses as well as demographic information of the participants. Given the relatively small sample size and unbalanced data, Shapiro–Wilk tests were performed to ensure data normality at the 95% confidence level. p values of the normality tests were <.05, which indicated that the data were not normally distributed. Therefore, for mean comparisons, instead of using t tests and ANOVA, Mann–Whitney U tests and Kruskal–Wallis tests (aka. ANOVA on ranks), nonparametric statistical approaches were performed to evaluate outcome differences between subgroups by independent variables. Additionally, Spearman correlation analyses (nonparametric) and univariate and multivariate regression analyses were performed to test the strength of association and linear relationships between and among variables. Principal component analyses were used to determine the factor structures of the scales. Moreover, to understand the overall relationships among variables, path analyses were conducted using IBM AMOS 24.0 and acceptable models were identified based on goodness-of-fit indices at the 95% confidence level.

Results

Participant profiles

In total, 93 participants (51 males and 42 females) partook in the experiment (Table 1). The average age for males was 24.92 (SD = 7.86, range 19–58), and for females, it was 25.02 (SD = 9.48, range 19–64). More than two-thirds of the participants (76.3%, n = 71) were Caucasians, with 6.5% (n = 6) Hispanics, 2.2% (n = 2) Asians, and 2.2% (n = 2) African-Americans. The participants’ height and weight were measured during the laboratory visit. The average height and weight for males were 71.06 inches (5 feet 11.06 inches, 180.49 cm, SD = 2.94) and 179.35 lb (81.35 kg, SD = 29.39), and for females, they were 65.38 inches (5 feet 5.38 inches, 166.07 cm, SD = 3.46) and 141.27 lb (64.79 kg, SD = 33.35). The average body mass index (BMI) for males was 24.10 (SD = 6.11, range 17–46), and for females, it was 24.56 (SD = 3.38, range 16–32).

Self-esteem

Factor structure of the scale

A principal component analysis (PCA) was performed to confirm the factor structure of the Rosenberg’s SE scale. To explain, the Rosenberg’s SE scale was originally conceptualized as a single-factor scale (Rosenberg 1965). However, since its development, the empirical factor structure of this scale has been a source of debate among researchers. That is, while several studies have suggested the scale is unidimensional with results from exploratory and confirmatory factor analyses (Baranik et al. 2008; Mannarini 2010; Song et al. 2011), some other studies have argued that the positive and negative dimensions of the SE scale lead to different outcomes, led by different experiences (Greenberger et al. 2003; Owens 1993; Sheasby et al. 2000). Given the mixed opinions on the factor structure of the SE scale, it was necessary to understand the dimensions of the scale with the data of this study. For the PCA, the varimax rotation method with Kaiser normalization was used at eigenvalues >1, and only items with a unique factor loading of .40 or greater were included, which led to the deletion of one item (out of 10). For the Rosenberg’s SE scale, the PCA results (Table 2) recommended a bi-dimensional two-factor structure measuring (a) negative dimensions of one’s self-esteem (self-depreciation; S1) and (b) positive dimensions of self-esteem (self-confidence; S2). The reliability coefficient of the first factor was .80 and the alpha score of the second factor was .79; thus, both factors demonstrated internal consistency among the included items. The PCA result supported the latter perspective (i.e., bi-dimensional) on the structure of the SE scale.

Relationships with background variables

Results of Mann–Whitney U tests determined no gender effects in the bi-dimensional two-factor structure of self-esteem at the 95% confidence level, in self-depreciation (Mann–Whitney U = 823.50, z = −1.744, p = .081) and self-confidence (Mann–Whitney U = 976.50, z = −.542, p = .588). In addition, results of Kruskal–Wallis tests confirmed no differences among BMI groups in self-depreciation (χ2 = 3.21, df = 2, p = .201) and self-confidence (χ2 = 2.53, df = 2, p = .282). Age did not also exhibit linear relationships with any of the dimensions in the SE scale, i.e., in self-depreciation (F = .614, df = 1, R = .082, β = .082, p = .435) and self-confidence (F = 3.343, df = 1, R = .189, β = −.189, p = .071). These results signified that the participants’ perceptions of self-esteem, either negative (self-depreciation) or positive (self-confidence), showed similar trends, regardless of gender, BMI and age.

Social physique anxiety

Factor structure of the scale

The SPA scale assesses the extent of anxiety experienced in response to having one’s physique evaluated by other people. A PCA determined that a two-factor structure would be appropriate and suitable for the data set. The first factor consisted of eight items (out of 12), which contained the items relevant to one’s other-oriented physique anxiety (P 1), and the second factor, containing four items, explained one’s self-oriented physique anxiety (P 2). Specific scale items, categorized in each factor, are listed in Table 3. Cronbach’s alpha reliability coefficients in each factor were .79 and .86, respectively. Scholarly debates in the academic literature address whether the unidimensional or bi-dimensional factor structure is appropriate for the SPA scale (e.g., Martin et al. 1997), and the results of this study supported the two-factor structure of the SPA scale, as the same trend was found with the Rosenberg’s SE scale.

Relationships with background variables

Mann–Whitney U tests revealed an interesting gender difference in the other-oriented physique anxiety factor (Mann–Whitney U = 477.00, z = −4.466, p = .000), while there was no gender difference in the self-oriented physique anxiety factor (Mann–Whitney U = 897.00, z = −1.167, p = .243). That is, men were less prone to be sensitive to others’ perspective on their physical appearance than women, but gender did not exhibit any significant effect on self-oriented physique anxiety. On the other hand, the results of linear regression analyses showed a statistical significance of BMI in the view of one’s body image on the SPA scale. That is, as BMI increased, the scores in both other-oriented and self-oriented physique anxiety increased with p = .008 and .000, respectively. This result indicated that participants who were heavier tended to report significantly greater anxiety with their physical self, with concerns regarding others’ evaluations (F = 7.34, df = 1, R 2 = .076, β = .276, p = .008) and feelings about their own body (F = 13.48, df = 1, R 2 = 132, β = −.363, p = .000). No differences were found in age in the SPA scores at p < .05.

Emotional responses to the 3D virtual body

Factor structure of the scale

To understand the general trend of the participants’ emotional reactions to viewing their 3D body, a PCA with varimax rotation was used to examine the factor structure of the 15-item emotion scale based on eigenvalues greater than 1. The result indicated three factors as the most appropriate structure. As the item content in Table 4 indicates, the first factor, consisting of five items, groups negative emotions toward external blame (threatened, fearful, resentful, downcast, and angry), and the second factor, consisting of eight items, measures negative emotions toward internal blame (dissatisfied, frustrated, embarrassed, uneasy, shameful, guilty, self-contempt, and anxious). The last two-item factor assesses positive emotions (excited, hopeful). Cronbach’s alphas indexed the internal consistency of the subscales, and the coefficient for Factor 1 (i.e., negative emotions toward external blame; E 1) was .93 and that for Factor 2 (i.e., negative emotions toward internal blame; E 2) was .94, indicating that the items in each subscale were consistent. The reliability of Factor 3 (i.e., positive emotions; E 3) was .47, which was not supported by the Cronbach’s test. Eisinga et al. (2013) argue that computing the reliability coefficient for a two-item scale is inappropriate and meaningless and recommended using the correlation coefficient as a measure of reliability. As suggested, Spearman correlation analysis was performed and the two items in Factor 3 were significantly correlated (p = .003), which affirmed the internal consistency of the last scale.

Relationships with background variables

To understand the gender effect on the emotional responses to viewing the 3D virtual body, Mann–Whitney U tests were performed. Data showed strong gender differences in the factors of negative emotions toward external blame (Mann–Whitney U = 662.50, z = −3.154, p = .002) and negative emotions toward internal blame (Mann–Whitney U = 619.50, z = −3.486, p = .000). More specifically, the mean ranks indicated that the female participants exhibited stronger negative emotions toward external blame and internal blame than the male participants. However, no gender difference was found in the positive emotions. Ethnicity presented an interesting trend in positive emotions toward the 3D virtual body, as the result of Mann-Whitney U tests indicated that Hispanics showed much stronger posisitve emotions toward viewing their 3D virtual body than Caucasians (p = .001; mean ranks 36.62 (Caucasian) vs. 67.33 (Hispanics)). There were no mean differences by BMI groups at the 95% confidence level. The results of linear regression analyses also demonstrated no age effects in all emotion types (p > .05).

Hypothesis testing

To understand the linear relationships of the SE and SPA variables with the types of emotions, regression coefficients were measured. A multivariate regression analysis was preformed to see the overall linear relationships among the two combined independent variables (self-confidence and self-oriented physique anxiety) and positive emotions. The result showed that there was no statistically significant relationship among the variables at the 95% confidence level (F = 3.007, df = 1, R 2 = .993, p = .282). However, univariate regression analyses suggested strong linear relationships between each independent variable (i.e., S 2 and P 2) and positive emotions. That is, positive emotions (E 2) showed a strong positive relationship with self-confidence (S 2) (F = 4.943, df = 1, R = .052, β = .229, p = .029) and a strong negative relationship with self-oriented physique anxiety (P 2) (F = 9.340, df = 1, R 2 = .094, β = −.307, p = .003). These results supported H1a and H1b, respectively.

Additionally, regression coefficients of negative emotions (E 1 and E 2) were evaluated with other-oriented physique anxiety (P 1). Since self-depreciation (S 1) did not have a strong correlation with negative emotions (H2a rejected), it was not included in the hypotheses testing. Negative emotions toward external blame (E 1) showed a strong positive relationship with other-oriented physique anxiety (F = 5.013, df = 1, R 2 = .053, β = .230, p = .028). Further, negative emotions toward internal blame (E 2) showed a positive relationship with other-oriented physical anxiety (F = .8.131, df = 1, R = .288, β = .275, p = .005). The results of the univariate regression analyses confirmed H2b. Based on the statistical results on negative emotions discussed above, H2 was partially supported.

Future willingness

At the end of the experiment, the participants were asked to rate their willingness to participate in a 3D body scanning session in the future. Overall, the participants indicated a positive attitude toward their willingness to use 3D body scanning to view their body (\(\bar{x} = 3.88\), out of 5, SD = 1.0092). The average score for men was 4.059 (SD = .7852) and that for women was 3.667 (SD = 1.2030), but the gender difference was not statically supported (Mann–Whitney U = 894.00, z = −1.447, p = .148) at the 95% confidence level. A univariate regression analysis determined that positive emotions were positively related to the participant’s future willingness to participate in the future session of 3D body scanning (F = 4.643, df = 1, R = .049, β = .222, p = .034). This result supported H3a. However, there were no other independent variables, including the SE factors (self-depreciation and self-confidence), SPA factors (other-oriented and self-oriented view), and negative emotions (negative emotions toward external blame and internal blame), which showed linear relationships with participants’ future willingness to view their 3D virtual body. The results suggested that although a participant exhibited negative self-esteem and strong social physique anxiety about his or her body, and even if the participant expressed negative emotions toward the 3D virtual body during the experiment, such negative measures were not necessarily transferred to the person’s future willingness to have another session of 3D body scanning and view the 3D virtual body, which rejected H3b. That is, regardless of their current psychological stance toward body image and the emotions they experienced from the 3D body scanning experience, overall the participants expressed a willingness to participate in another session of 3D body scanning to view their virtual body in the future.

Path analysis

In order to comprehend the overall relationships among the variables (i.e., 3 emotions, 2 SE factors, 2 SPA factors), path analyses were performed. To examine the causal relationships that affected one’s emotions and his or her willingness to participate in 3D body scanning, preliminary path models were extended to future willingness (W 1). Model 1 (Fig. 2) illustrates path relationships among self-confidence (S 2), positive emotions (E 3), and future willingness to participate in 3D body scanning (W 1). Self-oriented physique anxiety (P 2) was originally included in the model, but since an acceptable model fit was not achieved (p < .05), it was deleted from the model. This decision was also supported by the results of multivariate regression analyses discussed earlier. The goodness-of-fit indices, in addition to the χ 2 statistic (χ 2 = 1.861, df = 1, p = .173), supported a good fit of Model 1 (CMIN = 1.861, NFI = .835, RMEA = .095). The path analysis diagram of positive emotions depicts that one’s self-confidence significantly affects one’s positive emotions evoked from viewing his or her 3D virtual body, which in turn influences his or her willingness to participate in another session of 3D body scanning in the future at the 95% confidence level.

Figure 3 delineates path relationships associated with negative emotions among other-oriented physical anxiety (P 1), negative emotions toward external blame (E 1), negative emotions toward internal blame (E 2), and future willingness (W 1). The fit of Model 2 was supported by the results of the goodness-of-fit indices (χ 2 = 2.11, df = 2, p = .900; CMIN = 1.05, NFI = .985, RMEA = .000). In contrast to the path model of positive emotions, Model 2 demonstrates that other-oriented physique anxiety affects one’s negative emotions, both toward external blame and internal blame, but the negative emotions did not influence his or her future willingness to participate in 3D body scanning.

Discussion and conclusion

This study verified causal relationships that led to certain types of emotions after viewing the 3D virtual body and the willingness to participate in a future session, within the domains of self-esteem and social physique anxiety. The findings affirmed that the psychological constructs measured in this study (i.e., self-esteem and social physique anxiety) provided important insights as determinant factors of emotional reactions associated with the viewing of one’s own body in the form of virtual reality. Specifically, this study demonstrated that viewing one’s own 3D virtual body aroused three different types of emotions: negative emotions toward external blame, negative emotions toward internal blame, and positive emotions. The first scale of psychological constructs, based on Rosenberg’s SE scale, presented the bi-dimensional, two-factor structure, whose factors assessed the negative dimension of self-esteem (self-depreciation) and positive dimension of self-esteem (self-confidence). Self-confidence was strongly associated with positive emotions. The second scale, the SPA scale, was explained by a two-factor structure, presenting the two different views of physique anxiety (i.e., the other-oriented and self-oriented). The other-oriented perspective illustrated positive correlations with negative emotions. In addition, the participants who showed positive emotions indicated a strong willingness to participate in another session of 3D body scanning in the future, but those with negative emotions also showed their positive willingness to participate in the future session. These results signified that regardless of their emotional responses to viewing their 3D virtual body (positive or negative), the participants were willing to experience the 3D virtual body in the future, which corresponded with the results of Loker et al.’s study (2004).

This study contributes to the growing field of virtual reality in body image applications using a novel approach. However, given the nature of exploratory research, limitations should be noted. Although the data collection process was time-consuming, given that each session took approximately 30–40 min, the relatively small sample size (n = 93) limited the generalizability of the findings. Additionally, the primary location for data collection was in a US midsized city, where the total percentage of Caucasians was approximately 80%. A balanced ratio of ethnic groups with a higher percentage of nonwhite participants is desirable. Moreover, it should be noted that the unbalanced numbers of the emotion scale (13 negative vs. 2 positive) could create a bias in the study data, which suggests adding more positive emotions in the scale for future research. Nonetheless, the data of this study demonstrated internal consistency and structural and convergent validity of the instrumental scales and presented statistical findings supported at the 95% or higher confidence level.

This study suggests an interesting perspective in explaining negative emotions evoked from the 3D virtual body experience from the perspective of the allocentric lock theory (Riva 2011; Riva et al. 2012). That is, the participants who are predominantly affected by the other-oriented view of body image may experience a mental conflict between their allocentric view of the body to which they are accustomed and the “new” egocentric perspective of their body on the computer screen. Such internal conflicts between the two perspectives of body image might have led them to experience emotional vulnerability, which was expressed in the form of negative emotions. As De Vignemont and Frith (2005) ascertained, virtual reality technology is important in that it can help those with body image disturbance who usually have a fixed other-oriented view of body image shift their perspective to the self-oriented position. The conditional premise in the implementation of the treatment strategy is the patient’s willingness to participate in the virtual reality treatment for body image disturbance. This study finding offers evidence that the virtual 3D body approach experimented in this study met the preposition, thus proposing the possibility to be used in clinical settings as a practical treatment method to help patients gain more positive self-concept and body image. In the literature, several virtual environment-based software systems have been developed and their effectiveness has been validated with clinical applications, e.g., body image disturbance and eating disorder (Ferrer-García and Gutiérrez-Maldonado 2012; Perpiñá et al. 1999). However, those virtual reality tools were mostly to create controlled, simulated environments in the virtual contexts. In that sense, the approach of this study was novel since it allowed to create a virtual avatar by simulating the participant’s physique, rather than the environment, which could better facilitate bodily self-consciousness or the “I” experience of one’s body in the virtual contexts (Blanke and Metzinger 2009).

Given the willingness to participate in a virtual reality treatment, it would be an interesting, potentially effective approach to allow the patient to spend as much time as he or she needs examining one’s virtual body to actually experience the transformation to the egocentric view. This exercise may require repetition over time until the desired level of learning is achieved. In the experiment for this study, after 3D scanning, the participants were offered an option to examine in private their simulated virtual body based on their anthropometric data using the 360-degree rotation and zooming function for as long as they wanted. Some stayed as long as several minutes, and some declined to examine the image, beyond a quick viewing of it. Future research is needed to collect scientific evidence regarding this assumption from well-designed experiments with patients with body image disturbance or eating disorders to prove the long-term clinical benefits of this novel approach. Moreover, it is desired to investigate into the influences of various demographic or environmental factors, beyond age, gender, and BMI measured in this study, on the effectiveness of a virtual reality treatment, such as cultural differences in the hegemonic ideal, experience of social pressure, or motivations for behavioral changes.
